bug.short_desc: Better CDORevision list implementation for UNINITIALIZED data

long_desc.thetext:
Also it will optimized CDOReferenceProxyImpl... we should not initialize all the index with that.
Maybe we should have something to start with as easy as the following :
If I want to load a list with size 1000 with no data initialized inside... we should not allocate the array or any CDOReferenceProxyImpl As soon as the application initialize something we can go like before. This will be a good start it will: - Abstract any details about how to manager the list internally.
It will be easier to optimize after that.
Simon
"Simon McDuff" <smcduff@hotmail.com> wrote in message news:flo58r$2vn$1@build.eclipse.org...
Hi EIke,
Do you think it will be good to have a List that have a better management of UNINITIALIZED value ?
At the moment, if the real size of a collection is 1000, we create an array of 1000, we initialized a few of them... after we put the other element at UNINITIALIZED.
Should the list have better management ? We could beneficiate with a better management internally.
- Improve serialization - Improve memory
Thank you
Simon

Eike,
CDOReferenceProxy are only useful in the case where we want to modify a list. Until we modify an object... it is useless. Right ?
The following is based on the assumption that the above is true.
I'm trying to have many implementations of CDOList (interface)
1 - List you keep track of the original index (deal with CDOReferenceProxy) Use mostly in the client when we want to modify a objects. It is what we have right now. 2 - Normal List. (Lazy initialize CDOReferenceProxy if needed)
3 - List that handle big list (chunked list) (not in the first patch)
Based on my first implementation of chunked list... The performance match a single list or better ... except in the case when we construct a list with small size. Too much overhead :-(
I will concentrate with the first two items but It is why we would have many implementation.
What do you think ?

(In reply to comment #1) > CDOReferenceProxy are only useful in the case where we want to modify a list. > Until we modify an object... it is useless. Right ? I'm not sure what you mean with useless/useful.
There are 36 places referencing CDOReferenceProxy. analyzeReferenceRanges(List<Object>) (2 matches) - org.eclipse.emf.cdo.protocol.revision.CDORevisionResolver analyzeReferenceRanges(List<Object>) (6 matches) - org.eclipse.emf.internal.cdo.CDORevisionManagerImpl CDOReferenceProxyImpl - org.eclipse.emf.cdo.internal.protocol.revision copyValues(Object[]) (2 matches) - org.eclipse.emf.cdo.internal.protocol.revision.CDORevisionImpl get(CDORevisionImpl, CDOFeature, int) (2 matches) - org.eclipse.emf.internal.cdo.CDOStore move(InternalEObject, EStructuralFeature, int, int) (2 matches) - org.eclipse.emf.internal.cdo.CDOStore remove(InternalEObject, EStructuralFeature, int) (2 matches) - org.eclipse.emf.internal.cdo.CDOStore resolveReferenceProxy(CDOReferenceProxy) (3 matches) - org.eclipse.emf.internal.cdo.CDORevisionManagerImpl resolveReferenceProxy(CDOReferenceProxy) - org.eclipse.emf.cdo.internal.server.RevisionManager resolveReferenceProxy(CDOReferenceProxy) - org.eclipse.emf.cdo.protocol.revision.CDORevisionResolver set(InternalEObject, EStructuralFeature, int, Object) (2 matches) - org.eclipse.emf.internal.cdo.CDOStore toArray(InternalEObject, EStructuralFeature) (2 matches) - org.eclipse.emf.internal.cdo.CDOStore visit(CDOListFeatureDelta) - org.eclipse.emf.internal.cdo.util.RevisionAdjuster visit(CDOSetFeatureDelta) - org.eclipse.emf.internal.cdo.util.RevisionAdjuster writeValues(ExtendedDataOutput, CDOIDProvider, int) (2 matches) - org.eclipse.emf.cdo.internal.protocol.revision.CDORevisionImpl
2 places where they are created: - CDORevisionImpl.copyValues() - CDORevisionImpl.readValues()
Only 1 place where resolve() can delegate to: - CDORevisionManagerImpl.resolveReferenceProxy()
I'm really not sure if you're right. Could be, but: - Client loads a first chunk of 100 refs from a 200 refs list - Client inserts 10 refs at pos 50 - Client attempts to read ref at pos 150
How does the framework know that in the original list the pos is 140 and not 150?
> The following is based on the assumption that the above is true. > > I'm trying to have many implementations of CDOList (interface) Good.
> 1 - List you keep track of the original index (deal with CDOReferenceProxy) > Use mostly in the client when we want to modify a objects. It is what we have > right now. See above, but yes ;-)
> 2 - Normal List. (Lazy initialize CDOReferenceProxy if needed) I'm not sure. Depends a bit on the above.
> 3 - List that handle big list (chunked list) (not in the first patch) Good. Do you already have an ideaon how to implement that? - array of ranges - hash-based ...

>>[SIMON] Until we modify an object... it is useless. Right ? >>[EIKE] >>I'm really not sure if you're right. Could be, but: >>- Client loads a first chunk of 100 refs from a 200 refs list >>- Client inserts 10 refs at pos 50 >>- Client attempts to read ref at pos 150
>>How does the framework know that in the original list the pos is 140 and not >>150?
[SIMON] You gave an example that you modify a list. In this case it is useful. My question was saying : Is it useless in the case where you don't have a modified list ?
[EIKE} > 3 - List that handle big list (chunked list) (not in the first patch) Good. Do you already have an ideaon how to implement that? - array of ranges - hash-based ...
[SIMON] I did an array of ranges. It also detect when it could merge. Ex:.
- Collection of size 100 Add ObjectA to index 10 Add ObjectB to index 10
Should be merge into one range.

Yes, I believe that in theory, if you don't modify a list, you don't change the indices as well. Thus storing an index in the proxy is useless ;-)
I also like the array of ranges based approach. I think it will be harder to integrate the lists properly into the framework than to just implement a smart list.
*** Bug 215690 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Reversioned due to graduation

Do we still need the following ?
CDORevisionResolver.analyzeReferenceRanges.
it is called by CDORevisionImpl.write... but I believe since we have deltas we don't need to do that again. (Only new objects use the write from client side... and we will not find any CDOReferenceProxy!)
What do you think ?
Seems to make sense! I think we had no deltas when we added partial collection...

The optimized list isn't completed yet but the first draft will allow us to be in good position.
This patch include the following fixes: 247382: ReferenceChunk isn't working with add/remove of list (CDOReferenceProxy) https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=247382
Also reduce footprint for the following objects CDOReferenceProxyImpl and CDOrevisionImpl - Removed CDORevisionImpl.resolver - Remove CDOReferenceProxyImpl.feature, CDOReferenceProxyImpl.revision
I created CDOList and CDOListFactory where for now uses CDOListImpl (simple MoveableArray).
It include also the change for CDOStateMachine into a simple list! It is faster!
Created attachment 112844 Patch v1 - tobe review
You forgot to include things into the patch (MoveableArrayList). Is "not final" the only change?
I like your effort to remove infrastructure state from our mass components (revision, reference-proxy)!
Strange, CDOListFactory has no package declaration. But compiles fine!

If I insert "package org.eclipse.emf.cdo.common.revision;" it even complains:
Syntax error on token "package", import expected
A bug in the JavaEditor! Forget my 2 previous comments...

Created attachment 112881 Patch v2
Reviewed, applied minor changes/comments, reformatted, ready to be committed.
Am I right that you also fixed the unnecessary mapOfContents in CDOStateMachine?

(In reply to comment #16) > Created an attachment (id=112881) [details] > Patch v2 > > Reviewed, applied minor changes/comments, reformatted, ready to be committed. > > Am I right that you also fixed the unnecessary mapOfContents in > CDOStateMachine? >
Yes it include it. Based on what you said I will create a new bugzilla. And fake a commit for that specific optimization.
I don't think it's necessary to file a separate Bugzilla because it's really internal.

Moving all open issues to 4.2. Open bugs can be ported to 4.1 maintenance after they've been fixed in master.
